title: Your guide to the best feminist events over the next six months
text:
The coming months are packed with exhibitions, panel discussions and summits dedicated to championing women’s achievements and challenging gender bias.

From a book club dedicated to female friendship to a live recording of Deborah Frances White’s chart-topping podcast The Guilty Feminist, there is a rich mix of events on the agenda.

And looking forward to next year to International Women’s Day 2020, the WOW – Women of the World Festival will be celebrating its 10-year anniversary.

We’ll tell you what’s true. You can form your own view. From 15p €0.18 $0.18 USD 0.27 a day, more exclusives, analysis and extras.

Here is our go-to guide of the most inspiring feminist events around the world making a positive difference for women.

The Feminist Book Society, London

The manifesto of Katy Loftus and Eleanor Dryden’s monthly book club is: “Feminist. Bookish. Curious. Inclusive. Challenging. Kind.”

This month they are joined by authors Anna Hope, Lotte Jeffs and Naomi Shimada to celebrate and discuss the theme ”It’s Cool to be Kind”. Expect lively and inclusive discussions on how to be kind to ourselves and others.

Gower Street Waterstones, London, 18 September. Find out more here.

Vagina Museum Special, London

The Vagina Museum in London is hosting a night dedicated to female sexuality this month as part of Emerge Festival, a series of events that describes itself as ”A Night At The Museum meets Glastonbury”.

The evening, which will feature workshops, exhibitions and talks celebrating the female anatomy, promises to take “a sledgehammer to the stigma and shame surrounding women’s anatomy and sexuality”.

Camden, London, 28 September. Find out more here

Glittery Clittery, Sheffield

Described as part “comedy cabaret, part interactive political rave”. Join the “clitterati” as they dismantle the patriarchy one song and dance at a time.

This fiercely feminist show features original live music, comedy, dancing and audience games.

Following only one rule: “You can have a d***, just don’t be a d***”, this night out promises to be a fun-filled, informative celebration of all things female.

Sheffield, 28 September. Find out more here.

Caroline Criado Perez book discussion, Manchester

Join campaigner and author Caroline Criado Perez to discuss her bestselling book, Invisible Women, with host Alex Clark at the Manchester Literature Festival.

Ms Criado Perez’s landmark work explores the ways technology – from smart phones to office temperatures and data biases – have affected everything from women’s health and wellbeing to how we live our lives.

Manchester, 6 October. Find out more here.

The Guilty Feminist Live, London

Join comedian Deborah Frances-White for an evening of fun and feminism as she records her award-winning podcast The Guilty Feminist live.

Ms Frances-White and her guests will debate and discuss the ever-perplexing world of womanhood and feminism.

With 50 million downloads in the last two years, she has quickly become one of the most successful podcasters around.

London, 21 October. Find out more here

World Woman Summit, Arkansas, USA

This two-day summit, hosted at the Clinton Presidential Centre in Arkansas, United States, will see the likes of Gloria Feldt, former president of Planned Parenthood and Pat Mitchell, editorial director of Ted Women, speak on topics ranging from food insecurity, climate change, sustainability, social entrepreneurship and emerging technology.

This year’s focus is “#RedefiningRules by women, for women and of women”.

Arkansas, United States, 22-23 November. Find out more here.

European Women in Technology, Amsterdam, Netherlands

With audit firm PWC reporting that only 5 per cent of leadership positions in the technology sector are held by women, Europe’s largest women in tech conference is a must-do for those interested in careers in the technology sector.

This summit will focus on the future of technology and women’s role in it. Topics and seminars range from big data and machine learning to how to fund a startup, leadership skills and more.

The diverse line-up features female industry leaders from tech giants such as Ebay, Netflix and Google; with added opportunities for networking and understanding industry trends.

Amsterdam, 26-27 November. Find out more here.

WOW – Women of the World Festival, London

Celebrating 10 years since its launch, the WOW – Women of the World Festival returns this year to explore the state of gender equality and celebrate women and girls across the globe.

This three-day event – which is set to coincide with International Women’s Day 2020 – will see author Emma Dabiri take to the stage and will even feature an ”Under 10s Feminist Corner” for your budding equality champions.

London, 6-8 March 2020. Find out more information here.

Women in the World Summit, New York, USA

Celebrating a milestone in the American women’s movement, next year’s Women in the World Summit will mark 100 years of American women winning the right to vote.

Their website describes the event as a “masterclass in female leadership and an accelerator for activism”.

Speakers range from CEOs and world leaders to artists, activists and peacemakers.

Previous speakers and panellists include American Vogue editor-in-chief Anna Wintour, filmmaker Ava DuVernay, Oprah Winfrey and PepsiCo CEO Indra Nooyi.

New York City, United States, 1-3 April, 2020. Find out more here.

WomenBeing Festival, Edinburgh

WomenBeing is a Scotland-based independent feminist magazine, and next March it is hosting the second-ever international interdisciplinary conference on gender studies and the status of women at Queen Margaret University, Edinburgh.

The programme promises to address the challenges facing women in today’s society, on the issues of gender equality and women’s rights around the world.

The event will feature talks, workshops, networking and more to “showcase diverse female role models to inspire women and girls to view entrepreneurship as a career option”.

Edinburgh, 8-11 March 2020. Find out more here.
